It was incredibly satisfying to discover the artist behind Stars and Boulevards was Augustana. They weren't a one-hit wonder after all ! I was just a decade late to the realization.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/radio.once #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Dreamworld
story:
I heard Dreamworld for the first time in the car by the big field on Winter Street approaching our house in Kingston. It was very obviously Midnight Oil, though I had never heard it before, and, as it turns out, from the album that broke them back in '87 when I was in elementary school. I'd have taken this one over #music/song{Beds Are Burning}.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/radio.once #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Dark Horse
story:
My most acute memory of Dark Horse, super popular at the time, was from within the confines of the hospital, where the resident teenagers who monopolized the radio tuned into channels that played it often. Later, @laura{Laura} and I teased @sid{Sid} and @annie{Annie} by mis-lyricizing the crescendo as "hey what's up with that ?" intstead of "there's no going back." It took a while for me to know what the real line was, actually.

#timeline/kingston.2  #media/radio #player/boombox #player/car.black.prius #popular

title: Nights on Broadway
story:
In an email discussion @q{Rob} let me know that Nights on Broadway was his favorite Bee Gees song, and that if we ever had another chance as a band he'd insist we cover it. I gave it a listen and got into it for a little while after that.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Wedding Day
story:
@laura{Laura} was appropriately excited for the latest Tori album, and made the requisite visit with @nicole.e{Nicole} to The Orpheum to catch her on tour, even though I decided not to join them this time.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/album #player/laptop.11 #current

title: Strangers
Younger Than Yesterday
story:
I was completely captivated by Real Estate that summer. My favorites were Younger Than Yesterday and #music/song{Green Aisles}. The latter precipitated idle imaginations about myself and @laura{Laura} during college, fictitious adventures loosely inspired by memories of visiting each other at respective colleges, concluding the same thing Real Estate did: "All those aimless drives / Our careless life style / It was not so unwise."

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: No Other Way
story:
Ray LaMontagne had a new album that summer, and given how in tune I felt with some of his recent offerings, particularly the hits #music/song{Beg, Steal, or Borrow} and #music/song{For the Summer}, I really wanted to like this one. I did to some degree, but my expectations may have been a bit too high.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/album #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: Caravan
story:
I had known since sometime during high school that @maura{Maura's} parents, perhaps her dad in particular, were - in addition to being #music/artist{Billy Joel} fans - fans of Melissa Manchester. That information didn't mean as much until I realized I had the convenient ability to explore her most popular offerings -- via Spotify, of course. Caravan became a staple of my soft rock playlists in the coming years.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Bait And Switch
story:
#music/song{Simple Song} had done some time on the radio, but I wasn't so into it, a bit disappointed that the new Shins could possibly fail to speak to me. For that reason I ended up a bit behind the curve, but eventually I decided to check out the rest of the album, at which point I fell for Bait And Switch.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #almost.current

title: Cruel World
story:
I tried to ride the Lana Del Rey wave, giving #music/album{Ultraviolence} a fair share of my attention, but it wasn't doing it quite as well for me as her previous offerings had. Still, that's not saying much, given the magnitude of my weakness for her last two releases. On balance I was happy to have more of her material at my disposal.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/album #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: Dangerous
story:
Dangerous was all over the radio and thus the quintessential commuting song of the summer of 2014. I had a sense that @justin{Justin} was in on this one too, probably a hint given via some social media connection.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/radio #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: Scarecrow
story:
My relationship with Counting Crows had been a bit of a roller-coaster historically, but I was right where I needed to be by the time of their 2014 release, fully prepared to let it blow me away. Scarecrow was the radio jam that clued me in, and I just couldn't get over it. I may have expressed that to @toland{John} at some point - who was always on my case to get on board with these guys - but probably not as forcefully as I should have.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/radio #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: The Queen Is Dead
story:
How on earth did I miss out on The Queen Is Dead for so long ? I had been all over The Smiths and #music/artist{Morrissey} in college and for a while after that, and had known for a while that The Queen Is Dead was the greatest album of all time according to an NME publication, but I just never found it. The title track didn't appear on any of their greatest hits I was familiar with, and never played on the radio either. Fortunately missing out for so long gave me something to get lost in come fall of 2014.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Buried Alive
story:
I was drawn into Logic by a short commercial while listening to Spotify (commercials work I guess) and I never looked back. I tried to push him on @leo{Leo}, a return favor for turning me on to #music/artist{Kanye}.

The chords and rhythms over which Logic was singing somehow brought me back to my childhood, particularly a vision of cold dark night outside the bay windows of the living room, a streetlight scene in an urban setting.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/album #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: Growing Pains III
story:
I have openly wished and regularly day dreamt about going back in time to one of the first two hundred or so times I heard the killer transition half way through Growing Pains III, just to submit to the schism when it was even more powerful than it still is.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/spotify #format/album #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: Animals
story:
I never had much to relate to @cj{CJ} about, my much younger oldest niece, but at some family gathering over that Holiday season we came to realize we were both fans of the latest from Maroon 5, all over the radio at the time.

#timeline/kingston.2 #media/radio #player/car.black.prius #popular

title: Sweet Ophelia
story:
I managed to find and attain an addiction to Sweet Ophelia before hearing it with @laura{Laura} on an episode of the Vampiaries. It usually happened the other way around.

This song and a group of others I was listening to at around the same time - #music/song{Bang Bang}, #music/song{Fancy}, #music/song{10,000 Emerald Pools}, #music/song{Yellow Flicker Beat} - constituted the closest foray into the pop music I was accustomed to hearing in the kitchen courtesy @laura{Laura's} (and by extension @sid{Sid's}) playlists and stations, with some overlap, even.

title: Long Night
story:
@sid{Sid} and I went on a date to Starbucks that winter, and I was enthralled by the music they were playing. I couldn't find a "now playing" display, but I was able to pick up a few of the lyrics and use the Internet to discover, satisfyingly, it was new Guster. Unfortunately the song and I fell out of favor a few months later due to a bad experience, which I explained to @laura{Laura} immediately after it happened.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: High
story:
My Spotify meanderings that winter led me from current pop and dance music, which overlapped with @laura{Laura's} @sid{Sid}-inspired playlists, to an even more extreme house music. High and #music/song{I Remember} were the two songs I kept in heavy rotation.
 
I once accidentally joined an in-progress work meeting with one of these songs blaring, by restarting my browser and involuntarily firing up the meeting app. @jd{JD} complimented my taste in music from the other end, revealing something about his own.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: Horizon
story:
Real Estate had a new album, and given my affinity for the previous one, I was drawn way in. Horizon turned out to be my favorite song discovered that year.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/album #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: Time

Yes, it was the Vampiaries again, @laura{Laura} and I were locked in. In the case of Time, I went straight to the computer while it was still playing on the TV to figure out what it was - it took me that immediately - but a lull followed, and I started to feel that perhaps I had overreacted. Then, however, a week or two later, I couldn't get enough of it, to the point that I even put it in its own playlist to listen to on repeat.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/tv.show #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/tv #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: Rising Green

In church one day that spring that the choir sang so beautifully I pulled out my phone to record the audio until they stopped. On playback, the lyrics were just decipherable enough that I could figure out what the song was with help from the Internet. It was a traditional song, but I found one version of it that well-represented and listened to it often.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Out of the Woodwork
Ex's & Oh's
story:
@laura{Laura} and I first heard Elle King and Ex's & Oh's on the ride home from Maine that summer. We took note of it then, and soon, obviously, it was the most popular song going. @annie{Annie} expressed a liking for the song, representing her earliest musical opinion I recognized.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/radio #player/car.black.prius #player/car.red.siena #popular

title: If The Creek Don't Rise
story:
"This is the second time I've ever heard this song," I told @laura{Laura}. It was. If The Creek Don't Rise by Dylan LeBlanc.

Years prior, while still living in Maynard, I heard what I was certain was Ray Lamontagne on a Sunday morning acoustic program. Especially given that the lyric was "God willing and the creek don't rise," because wasn't that the name of his album ?

I didn't find the song after that. Maybe I didn't try hard enough. When I remembered it might be worth a try again some years later one morning in our Kingston kitchen, it was pretty easy to find.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.11 #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Elastic Heart
story:
My introduction to Sia was when she helped #music/artist{Kanye} perform #music/song{Wolves} at the SNL 40th reunion show, but shortly thereafter she was everywhere. I guess that #music/song{Chandelier} song that was oft borrowed for reality style singing shows was hers, I just didn't realize it. Elastic Heart blew that one away, though. It was one of the two pop songs of the summer -- see also: #music/song{Invincible}, #music/artist{Kelly Clarkson}.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/radio #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/car.red.siena #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: Things Happen
story:
@greg{Greg} and @laura.k{Laura} rented @uncle.jack{Uncle Jack's} place in Manomet for a week that summer, and the rest of the local siblings - @al{Al}, @pete{Pete}, and myself - converged to participate in their vacation for a day, families in tow. 

As the evening wore on, we got to listening to 104.7 on the back porch, which was apparently Uncle Jack's advice. I was thrilled to hear that. 104.7 was one of my six presets, despite that it faded out after only a quarter of my commute. 

I asked Greg that night if he had ever heard of Dawes. He hadn't. I told him I thought he would like them, a nod to their modern take on a softer sort of rock.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/radio #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac #popular

title: How Big, How Blue, How Beautiful
Birds vs Worms

The last song on the mix @bill{Bill} made for me that summer was my favorite, but without liner notes, I had no idea who it was. I eventually looked into it and discovered it was Modest Mouse. When I explained that to Bill, he told me he included the song specifically because he thought I was a fan, likely due to the fact that @laura{Laura}, @shawn{Shawn}, @alicia.w{Alicia}, and myself went to see them at Harborlights around that time.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/cd.burned #format/mix.received #player/car.black.prius #almost.current

title: Out To Sea
Iron Moon

Chelsea Wolfe was a blessing of a discovery, delivering the darkness without irony or apology. I did something that fall that I almost never do -- I looked up her tour schedule, to see if she was playing anywhere near Boston soon. Surprisingly, she was slated for The Sinclair just a month out, but unsurprisingly it was sold old. Yes, unsurprising even though I had never heard of her before. It just made sense that she had some kind of following.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #almost.current

title: Compton
story:
When I told @leo{Leo} to look into #music/artist{Logic}, he told me to look into Kendrick Lamar, and so I did. It was a bit slow to take off -- I started with #music/album{To Pimp A Butterfly}, and went for a few of them initially - #music/song{These Walls}, #music/song{How Much A Dollar Cost}, #music/song{The Blacker The Berry} - but ultimately came to appreciate a great deal. 

As for his older stuff, I didn't get too far there either, but I did find the gem Compton, and may have grown to like it more than anything else I had heard of his. As @laura{Laura} knows, after hearing me preach it a hundred times or more: 

Look who's responsible for taking Compton international !

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Wildest Dreams
story:
@toland{John} tried numerous times to impart to me the power of Ryan Adams album full of #music/artist{Taylor Swift} #music/album{1989} covers before I actually gave it a chance. When I did, it was due to the realization that the song on the radio I had fallen for was in fact - somewhat to my dismay - Taylor Swift. I explained to John that, for whatever reason, finding out a song was sung by Taylor Swift, even though I had sort of suspected it, was similar to seeing an attractive woman in public, only to then realize she was walking a dog. Kinda ruined it for me, for reasons ostensibly irrelevant.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/album #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #current

title: Streetlife Serenader
story:
I was way into a developing a long playlist of all worthy soft rock throughout a good portion of 2015. Around November I got to adding Billy Joel, at which point I realized something I felt inclined to share with my Billy Joel confidants, @pete{Pete} and @maura{Maura}, even though I never did (until right now): Streetlife Serenader was my favorite Billy Joel song. 

I liked it back when too - Pete had the live version on #music/album{Songs In The Attic}, which we listened to plenty - but I think back then I was a little more into #music/song{Surprises}, at a minimum, and maybe others.

title: Pass You By
story:
It was so cool that the True Blood series @laura{Laura} and I were binge watching towards the end of that year displayed the name of the song and artist when we hit pause. That made it so simple to figure out I needed to add Pass You By to my Spotify playlist.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/tv.show #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/tv #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Gone Away
story:
For some reason early in 2016, I thought I wanted to give away most of my records. I pulled out the bins, organized them, cataloged them, and posted my intentions to Facie. Among those ready to relieve me of a few of them were @abby{Abby} and @tate{Tate}, but I just couldn't get by the backlash -- too many people asked what the hell I was doing for me to go through with it.

In the process I made a few new discoveries. Among the best of them was #music/album{Chapter Two} by Roberta Flack, particularly the song Gone Away.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/record #media/spotify #format/album #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Poor places
story:
After an initial spell with #music/album{Yankee Hotel Foxtrot}, I gave it another go and realized there were not two but three songs that stood out well above the others: #music/song{I am trying to break your heart} and #music/song{Radio cure} I knew about, but add Poor places. I relayed this info to @shawn{Shawn} and @toland{John} while gathered at Shawn's house some time thereafter.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/album #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Next Time Around
story:
I fell in love with Sandy Denny in the spring of '16. I hadn't known her so well before that. 

I liked her song on #music/artist{Midlake's} compilation of songs by their inspirations, which I had discovered a couple years before; and I knew she was the female voice in #music/artist{Fairport Convention}, but I didn't know them so well either; plus, every time I ever read anything about #music/artist{Pentangle}, who I had been into long before, they cited #music/artist{Jacqui McShee's} voice - which I found angelic and almost incomparable - as the best of sixties British folk -- besides Sandy Denny.

title: Kiss This

@kat.b{Kat} asked me about The Struts almost every time I saw her for a couple years. I had not heard a thing about them otherwise. Then some song on the radio held my fancy and, to my delight, turned out to be this band she had been talking about for so long. I was thrilled to be able to tell her that the night @mike.b{Mike} sent out the call to let friends know they'd be at The New World Tavern in case anybody wanted to join, which I did, and I did.

title: That's Life, tho (almost hate to say)

I was pretty sure it was a crossover song by a country artist, and that in following up I'd be wandering into country territory, like I had done previously with #music/artist{Eric Church} and #music/artist{Dierks Bentley}, but instead I found an artist that defied categorization in Kurt Vile. title: Wuthering Heights
story:
Like so many songs around those years, Wuthering Heights followed the familiar pattern of straight from discovery on the radio to Spotify playlist and in turn familiarity. I have a feeling there's much more Kate Bush that I would thoroughly enjoy but as of yet am unacquainted with. 

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/radio.once #media/spotify #format/playlist #player/car.black.prius #player/laptop.work.mac

title: Delilah

It's hard to explain the delay in falling for Delilah, since it was on the same album I had listened to quite a bit the year before, but it became my Florence fix for 2016.

#timeline/kingston.3 #media/spotify #format/album #format/playlist #player/laptop.work.mac #almost.current

title: Sorry
story:
I always liked Justin Bieber's story, a persistent and true artist, it seemed, despite that I had no great familiarity with his music, until #music/song{As Long As You Love Me}, which I really liked. I had great sympathy for him as a person amid a troubling series of very public escapades in young adulthood, and rooted for him to pull himself together. He seemed to have to done so by the summer of '16, with decent high-profile appearances on the approach, and that's when Sorry hit the radio. At that point I became a Belieber.

title: Dark Necessities

Somehow the Chili Peppers managed to (paraphrasing @leo{Leo} when we heard Go Robot riding home after a C's game) still sing like that, and still play like that, like one long song, that just keeps on going.

title: The Incredible True Story
story:
The Incredible True Story became my most listened to song of 2016. I tried the album once before, right when it came out, most of a year prior, but it didn't quite catch on. That was hard to process by the time I tried again, because I was so into it, particularly the final and title track, The Incredible True Story.

title: Love Yourself
story:
Such a fan of the lyrics and tone of Love Yourself, I kept the radio on the pop stations just to hear it. I was uncertain who it was, which is saying something, since I obviously knew Justin Bieber and some of his other songs. At one point in conversation @laura{Laura} told me it was #music/artist{Nick Jonas}, and I believed that for a while, until a radio DJ finally spoke the truth, at which point I described for Laura this progression.

title: Saint Pablo
story:
I checked back on Spotify so many times for Kanye's #music/song{Wolves} after he performed the song on the SNL special a couple years prior, but it took a long time for him to release the album, and even when he did, it wasn't on Spotify initially. Finally it was, and Saint Pablo became the one I listened to most. Absolutely loved the reference to Where's Waldo. And wondered how into this latest Kanye album @leo{Leo} was.

title: Double Talkin' Jive
story:
A bunch of us went to see Guns N' Roses that summer - @laura{Laura}, @shawn{Shawn} and @alicia{Alicia}, @toland{John} and @katie.f{Katie}, plus a few others - and man, was it fun. Alicia was the biggest fan, and so we sort of took our cues from her. 

I figured @j{J} was probably going too, and so I called him the day of the show. Of course he was, with @k{K}. We tried to coordinate a meeting but it didn't work out. We did text during the show, however, particular when Double Talkin' Jive came on. I didn't know that one so well (when the #music/album{Use Your Illusions} came out during high school, I got disc 2 for Christmas, not disc 1, though @greg{Greg} did), but J went nuts. Alicia was clearly into it as well, singing along with every word.

title: Sleight Of Hand
story:
@shawn{Shawn} got Pearl Jam tickets for both of their Fenway shows that summer, four seats each. I signed up for the second show, along with @toland{John}, and we roped in @jim{Jim}, too, despite that he was going to the first show as well. Excitement was peak when we met @spoth{Spoth} and @leith{Leith} and their band of merry show-goers at a bar ahead of time, everybody in the neighborhood buzzing with anticipation.

In advance of the show, in order to work up my enthusiasm, I picked up where I had left off with Pearl Jam, playing almost exclusively from their sixth studio album, #music/album{Binaural}. #music/song{Rival} and Sleight Of Hand were the two songs I played the most.

By the time of the show, after some thought, I think I had decided that #music/song{Hold On}, an unreleased track from the #music/album{Versus} era, and perhaps #music/song{I Got Id}, were my favorite Pearl Jam songs. They weren't played that night, unfortunately. They did play #music/song{Footsteps}, however, which I hadn't heard in a long time, but had been quite familiar with thanks to a CD loan from a busboy I didn't know so well at Bobby Hackett's restaurant during high school, so I got into that one again for a while after the show, too.

title: Tell Me When It's Over
story:
#music/artist{Jay Mascis'} appearance on stage with #music/artist{Pearl Jam} at Fenway that summer did two things to me. First, it knocked my musical taste off its axis, as I got back into whatever #music/artist{Dinosaur Jr} and related I had ever been into and more. Second, it led me down some rabbit hole following a trail of artists similar to, influenced by, or otherwise related to each other, until I finally arrived at The Dream Syndicate. @kirk{Kirk}, at @maura{Maura's} birthday party dinner shortly thereafter, mentioned #music/artist{The Soft Boys} in a conversation about music, who I would not have known of if not for following that trail so recently, coincidentally.

By the end of the summer, I was considering whether #music/album{The Days of Wine and Roses} was one of my ten favorite albums of all time. @annie{Annie}, of her own volition, perhaps after hearing me sing along, would sing aloud as a lark: "tell me when it's over. oh let me know when it's done !" She had surprisingly perfect affectation, almost Dylanesque.

title: Shitty Fiction
story:
Greenland is a band I regularly checked in on. That year they were releasing another album, which they had on bandcamp well before the official release, and so I turned off Spotify for a while and listened only to #music/album{Shitty Fiction}. The opening felt like a drug after long withdrawal. I loved #music/song{Antediluvian Nights} from first listen on. I fell equally hard for the second track, #music/song{Ghost at My Elbow}. Only one track was better than those two, and all the rest of them for that matter - the title track - with its blistering opening and relentless attack.
